🎄🎄🎄@holeandcorner advent calendar is now alive! Haniwa warrior give away started. 🎄🎄

HOHOHO.

REPOST LIVE 🎄🎄🎄🎄
@holeandcorner
Win one of Noe Kuremoto’s wonderfully curious sculptures which are inspired by the ancient Japanese icons that adorned her house as she grew up. ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Each icon carried a meaning or moral that has stuck with Kuremoto and, by giving sculptural form to these symbols, she hopes to bring an element of spirituality into your home.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Kuremoto is offering two lucky winners a sculpture from her Haniwa collection. The Haniwa were traditional clay figures buried with the dead during the Kofun period of Japan, in the belief that they would protect souls in the afterlife. Kuremoto’s Haniwa figures are designed to protect our souls in this world by inspiring us to take risks and pursue our passions in order to prevent our souls from growing weak. ⠀⠀⠀⠀
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
To enter:⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
- Follow us @holeandcorner + @noe_kuremoto_ceramics⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
- Like this post and tag a friend who you’d think like this gift⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
- They must also like this post and follow both accounts⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
- Share this post on your story for an additional entry⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
- Deadline: 12am midnight today. ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The winners will be announced tomorrow! Good luck!⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

DOGU LADIES 
My interpretation of the ancient Dogu*.
A talisman for women today.
Who build a career, a life and raise children.
With no precedent to guide us - we work it all out as we go.
My Dogu Ladies watch over us as we make history.
 
*Dogu - mysterious female figurines from prehistoric Japan (14,000-400BC approx). With big eyes, accentuated large breasts and wide hips, they are widely held to be symbols of fertility, a promise of safe delivery for baby and mother, hope for the continuation of life.

.

If you are curious about my Project Dogu lady please read my previous post. 

.

Dear Young me
 
“…Motherhood is the last thing on your mind, and you too easily neglect your personal life in favour of achieving professional success. The price is paid by your partner who dreams of fatherhood…”
 
“….You always put work ahead of everything else that matters. And your marriage suffers because you’re ill prepared for motherhood. Your partner has an easier time of it. Children represent the most important thing for him, he’s certain of it. You wish it was as clear to your soul. However, it is not…”
 
 
“..At the same time, deep inside of you, you’re unsure if you are really be okay with never having children in your life…”
 
 
A letter to young me.
 
Love from 40 something me to 20 something me.
 
.
 
 
My letter will not fit into this space so please read my post if you like. I will share them over next 3 days.
 
 
Thank you.
 
.
 
Forever grateful for my dearest friends who I can trust with my darkest secret.
 
Copy support by Jason @larklife 
Photography by @kes_____ 
.
.
.

Dear Young me PT2
 
“…The biggest fear…Children are the enemy of your professional success.”
 
“….Your other big fear…What if you’re a terrible mother? “
 
 
“…Motherhood is the last thing on your mind, and you too easily neglect your personal life in favour of achieving professional success. The price is paid by your partner who dreams of fatherhood…”
 
“..At the same time, deep inside of you, you’re unsure if you are really be okay with never having children in your life…”
 
 
 
A letter to young me.
 
Love from 40 something me to 20 something me.
 
.
 
 
My letter will not fit into this space so please read my post if you like. I will share them over next 2 days.
 
 
Thank you.
 
.
 
Forever grateful for my dearest friends who I can trust with my darkest secret.
 
Copy support by @larklife 
Photography by @kes_____ 

.

Dear Young me PT3
 
“Your work provides you with a huge source of pleasure…Yet it’s also your biggest curse. Curse because there’s never a good time to stop working, to get pregnant…”
 
 
“…your marriage suffers because you’re ill prepared for motherhood. Your partner has an easier time of it. Children represent the most important thing for him, he’s certain of it. You wish it was as clear to your soul. However, it is not….”

“..At the same time, deep inside of you, you’re unsure if you are really be okay with never having children in your life…”

A letter to young me.

Love from 40 something me to 20 something me.

.

So this is the complete letter. Thank you so much for all your messages and comments. I am reading them all and I will reply to every single one. Please bear with me. I will reply once the kids are zzz but it may take sometime, as I want to put my heart into it. 

Lots of love and strength
 
Noe xx

.

Forever grateful for my dearest friends who I can trust with my darkest secret.

Copy support by @larklife
Photography by @kes_____

.

New exhibition 'Postcards of Rotterdam' 🇳🇱

Curated by Objects with narrative @objectswithnarratives 
In collaboration with DOEN Rotterdam @doen.do 

Private view: 10 February 2023

Group exhibition with Alfie's Fuzzy Friends, Alissa Volchkova, Cedric Breisacher, Frédéric Saulou, Freia Achenbach, Hakmin Lee, Johan Viladrich, Laura Sattin, Laurids Gallée, Lukas Cober, Jan Ernst, Noe Kuremoto, Maria Tyakina, OWL, Pietro Franceschini, Pierre De Valk, Raphael Kadid, Roxane Lahidji, Sarah Roseman, Six N. Five, Studio Nienke Hoogvliet, Studio Pei Pei, Studio ThusThat , Supertoys Supertoys, Tim Vranken, Ward Wijnant
-
In celebration of a new beginning, we reminisce about the history of a former post office through three-dimensional postcards. Travelling through an industrial space, one gains insight into a diverse collection where each piece is in dialogue with its surroundings. The architecture guides you through different scenes, from gallery arrangements and displays of colour, to eventually moving into a loft-like living space. The building features a unique volume in disguise of a vault that highlights a compelling interplay. Each object with a voice of its own, offers an engaging experience that is revealed as the space unfolds.
-
DOEN, Avenue Concordia 30, 3062 LJ Rotterdam, Netherlands

Photo : @kes_____

Group exhibition with Alfie's Fuzzy Friends, Alissa Volchkova, Cedric Breisacher, Frédéric Saulou, Freia Achenbach, Hakmin Lee, Johan Viladrich, Laura Sattin, Laurids Gallée, Lukas Cober, Jan Ernst, Noe Kuremoto, Maria Tyakina, OWL, Pietro Franceschini, Pierre De Valk, Raphael Kadid, Roxane Lahidji, Sarah Roseman, Six N. Five, Studio Nienke Hoogvliet, Studio Pei Pei, Studio ThusThat , Supertoys Supertoys, Tim Vranken, Ward Wijnant
-
In celebration of a new beginning, we reminisce about the history of a former post office through three-dimensional postcards. Travelling through an industrial space, one gains insight into a diverse collection where each piece is in dialogue with its surroundings. The architecture guides you through different scenes, from gallery arrangements and displays of colour, to eventually moving into a loft-like living space. The building features a unique volume in disguise of a vault that highlights a compelling interplay. Each object with a voice of its own, offers an engaging experience that is revealed as the space unfolds.
-
DOEN, Avenue Concordia 30, 3062 LJ Rotterdam, Netherlands

Ieskomas asistentas darbui keramikos studijoje.

IESKOME ENTUZIASTINGO IR ORGANIZUOTO.

Noe Kuremoto keramikos studija randasi Pasarciu kaime. Tai puiki proga suprasti ir ismokti kaip organizuojami, bei igivendinami darbai profesionaliose meno, keramikos dirbtuvese. Tai isties gera proga asmenybei norinciai tobulinti, bei  plesti savo kurybiniu igudziu lauka.

DARBU POBUDIS:

Efektyviai atlikti kasdienius studijos darbus - modeliavimas, glazuravimas, degimas, tvarkymas, molio gryninimas, pakavimas.

KO JUS ISMOKSITE:

Keramikos techniku pritaikymas – modeliavimas, glazuravimas, degimas.
Kurti skulpturas is molio
Kaip konceptualizuoti idejas ir jas realizuoti savo asmenineje kolekcijoje
Kaip komunikuoti su klientais, priimineti klientu uzsakymus ir juos realizuoti 
Kaip organizuoti parodas
Kaip vystyti savo menininko portfolio ir kaip reklamuoti save meno, bei  kurybos sferoje
Kaip vystyti savo asmenines kolekcijas.
KO MES TIKIMES IS JUSU:

Butu tobula, jeigu jus turetumete menines patirties, ar patirties darbe su keramika. Jeigu patirties neturite – nebeda, svarbiausia buti kurybingu 
Organizuotumo ir kruopstumo
Noro mokytis
Gebejimas dirbti kelis darbus vienu metu (“multitaskinti”)
Neprarasti koncentracijos itemptose situacijose.
TAI TINKA TIEMS KAS…

Iesko progos isitvirtinti kurybos pasaulyje ir auginti savo, kaip meninko, profili
Myli gamti. Dirbtuves randasi pamiskeje prie ezero.
Iesko progos dirbi meno studijoje pilnoje entuziazmo, bei siekti bendru tikslu
Domisi menais ir/arba keramika
Yra motivuotas kilniu tikslu
Darbas puse ir/arba pilnu etatu.

Thank you for everyone who came to the exhibition @collectiblefair 🤍🤍🤍
🤍🤍🤍Repost  love 🤍🤍🤍@objectswithnarratives 
'What's For Dinner' - Collectible Brussels 2023 with works of Alun Heslop, Cedric Breisacher, Dim Atelier, Faina, Hakmin Lee, Jan Ernst, Laura Sattin, Laurids Gallée, Lisa Ertel, Lukas Cober, Maria Tyakina, Mira Sohlen, Mircea Anghel, Pierre De Valck, Raphael Kadid, Roxane Lahidji, Sabourin Costes, Sarah Roseman, Six N. Five, Steven Edwards, Supertoys Supertoys, Tim Vranken, Ward Wijnant & William Guillon
Pictures by @studio.brinth
-
This year, Collectible 2023 - the fair that celebrates unique objects - takes place at the renowned Tour et Taxis Brussels, a cultural hub at the center of the historical industrial quarter of Brussels whose origin dates back to the Industrialisation in Belgium at the end of the 19th century. The contradiction between the annual event and its location is the starting point of our narrative: to celebrate the opposite of the Industrial Revolution: craftsmanship (the human act of mastering the elements of earth, fire, water, wind and the primitive forces that still run within our modern needs.)
The exhibition is not defined by a style, material or process but defined by a single dedicated room that brings people together and closest to these natural elements: the dining room. This space acts as a podium where craftsman from over 15 different cultures over the world can express themselves. Each collected object, with a story of its own, comes together to join the narrative of a ritual we share universally. This is an invitation to reconnect through the materials and processes of a timeless design collection that takes us back to a place where we find comfort and made us human after all.
.
.
.

In Japan, every new year we hung Shimekazari above the door to our home.
To purify it and prevent bad spirits entering. 

Simekazuri - braided straw rope, daidai (a bitter orange), and fern leaves.
We believe the woven rope is stronger then a single rice straw, so it keeps the impurity away from a sacred place - the ‘family home’. In Japan, the rope is a common way to mark an object or space. When hung above an entrance (usually a shrine or ritual site), it marks the border to pure space where the gods can descend.

Daidai oranges ripen during harsh winter and stay on the tree for a long time, often more than a year, so the tree has multiple generations of the fruits together and is seen as a symbol of family prosperity. (The Daidai orange is considered a good omen because if it is written with a different kanji it can be translated as ‘from generation to generation’).

The ferns are symbols of hope and desire for a happy family, growing from generation to generation. The underside is white, and considered to represent honesty, and they always grow in pairs. So are seen as a faithful couple growing old together.

Stay in tuned for my next collection Shimekazari.

Thank you

In my 20’s and 30’s like many women I suffered from an ‘allergy’ to marriage and motherhood. I believed that so long as I was an independent career woman, I’d do just fine, thank you very much. And I was just that, until life hit my head with a sledge hammer. Death. Serious illness. Financial crisis. Pandemic. My belief system collapsed. Worse still, my belief in belief systems collapsed. Now what? Here I was in my mid 30’s, held prisoner by my younger self’s definition of success. Maybe I wasn’t enough of a die-hard artist?  As I hung our Shimekazari* above our door this past New Year, it made me wonder why our ancestors felt the family’s soul needed protection from evil spirits.  What I actually needed was the same as most people: A stable intimate partner, a family, a home, a career.  And as it turned out, having a family helped me become someone who could better identify my creative capabilities, be more creatively courageous, more able to articulate and put into action my art, and better pursue my ‘noble’ goals. Family life takes serious cultivation, certainly. And we must fight the temptations of our own idiosyncrasies. Perhaps these are the evil spirits Shimekazari defend us from rather than some evil sprits from a mysterious hell?  Flawed as I am as a human being, a wife, a mother - family offers me the possibility of becoming so much more than I am, under Shimekazari*. And though there’s no evidence it will work out - I commit to it.  Wholeheartedly. If you’re ready to turn ‘not the right time’ into the time of your life, please dive into the eternally beautiful ocean of family with me. It’s intense. Crazy fun. And fundamentally human.
 
Here’s to family.
The eternal beauty.
 
(Please see the slide 3 for the unedited version.  Thank you )

.
Photography: @kes_____

For us who are allergic to motherhood.
For us who are allergic to marriage.
For us who run from the idea of family and have done for longer than we care to admit.
For we who are wedded to careers where family falls unintentionally second.
Who are unsure about what family even means exactly.
Who ask - Do we really need a family to enjoy a fulfilled life?
Who wonder with our rapidly changing world, is it still the most important thing?
For us who fear of losing our freedom.
For us who feel the need to create an independent life, in case of break up.
For us who think marriage is just a piece of paper.
Or wonder, why bother when almost 50% of marriage ends in divorce?
For us who feel a mortgage and a dog are more than enough to show commitment.
For us held prisoner to our younger self’s definition of success.
For us who cling to the dusty belief a successful career alone can build a fulfilled life.
Who question whether a ‘real artist’ can thrive without food, warmth, roof or family.
For us die-hard artists in our 20’s whose steam runs out in our 30’s.
For us who seek answers of our own, rather than rely on traditional or ancestral wisdom.
For us who strive to live beyond cultural norms, yet whose soul cries out for the ‘ordinary everyday dreams’ of intimate partner, family and home.
Who trust in self-help podcasts to pull our lives together though they merely dull our pain for 5 mins.
For us hungry to correct the wrongs of our own childhood by doing things differently.
Who are ready to spar with life.
Ready to explore how remarkable it is to be alive.
For us who know a stable heart helps us tackle an uncertain future.
Who believe we can create an earthly heaven in our own home.
 
Here’s to family.
To this eternal beauty.
Where we step into the unknown together even without evidence it will work out.
Let’s seize the gift of faith family brings with both hands.
Flawed as I am, as a human being, a wife, a mother – family helps me become more than I am, under Shimekazari.
If you’re ready to turn ‘not the right time’ into the time of your life,
please dive into the eternally beautiful ocean of family with me.
It’s intense. Crazy fun. And fundamentally human.

“In my 20’s and 30’s I had an ‘allergy’ to marriage and motherhood.  And I know I’m not alone in questioning social conventions. Do we really need a family?…”
 
 
“Marriage is just a piece of paper -yes? Life with a mortgage and our sausage dog Lassie seemed more than enough commitment….”
 
“Was I  held prisoner to my younger self’s definition of success?....”
 
“Can we live ‘happily ever after’ with simply a career we love, a boyfriend and a dog?”
 
 
I am so glad my personal journey of motherhood and wifehood has resonated with so many people. Wow. I am overwhelmed and so touched by every single message and endless beautiful comments. It’s so gratifying that it is almost too much! The social media platform is never an easy space for me to be completely ‘naked’ emotionally but I am glad I clicked ‘share’! Unbelievably fortunate to have people sharing their incredibly intimate stories with me. Thank you for allowing me to be a part of your journey. It’s so stunning.
 
(If you would like to read more please go to the slide 2. Thank you.)
 
.

Thank you Kes.

When Japanese Mountain Gods appear as children, they are known as Satori. Satori can read your mind. They can speak your thoughts faster than words fall from your lips. Should they hear you lie, they might kill, or even eat you. From an early age, I knew what their story meant - that every lie you tell brings your soul a little closer to death. In Japan, the death of your soul is worse than death itself.

I can still remember the details of my mum’s hand. The way she files her nails neatly. How her hands carried the scent of fresh ginger and spring onion. The way she moves her fingers in the air when she is not practicing the piano. As an adult person I can still picture my mother’s hands clearly but I cannot picture the details’ of Issey’s painting from this morning. I only remember a vague shape and it is already blurred and I have not even fed them their lunch yet. It is scary how absent I can be. The children has a very deep sense of belonging to now. That’s something I lost on the way to adulthood and career focus life. I started my new collection with just a blob of clay and I finish making a sculpture in one go. Just to test myself how deeply I can practice belonging to now. Can I still see the richness of the world the way they can see? 
Have a great day everyone.

After focusing on my exhibition prep for weeks and weeks,  Issey hurt himself in the garden and he is crying as if he lost his entire leg. Both of us go out to the garden to see if he is ok, then Issey runs into Ed’s arms to get comfort. I could not help myself but felt my heart sank. As I was less present in his life, I was no longer his main source of comfort. I should have felt grateful that Ed is a great supporter of my career and he steps into full-time parenthood when I ask for help. Why do I still want to be the first one to be asked for a hug? Is any mama out there feeling the internal conflict too?😢
.

I sketched this one in the middle of the night when I went back to work for the first time after Issey (our first son) was born. I decided to work as if I don’t have a baby. I was afraid to stay at home too long and become unfulfilled, not advancing my career  and feeling lost in the midst of motherhood. The first day back at work, a part of me felt liberated from endless nappy changes and relentless breastfeeding. (Although pumping wasn’t easy.) After 8 hours away from my baby for the first time, I cycled as fast as I could to my baby son. The smell of our nanny’s perfume on him stopped my heart. I could not breathe. I’m the one who wanted everything both motherhood and career so I have no right to be upset-so I told myself. That night once I put him to sleep, I made this quick sketch. My heart was racing with a thought that after 8-9 hours in somebody else’s arms my baby was going to start loving me a little bit less. Worse, he may start loving her instead. I knew working mother life will be difficult but these feelings I was not prepared for. It feels like a long time ago now. Anyhow I started to do quick sketches in-between breast-feeding routines. My collection of sketches became a proof of ‘progress’. I needed to know that I am still one step closer to who I want to become as a human and an artist. Do you remember the first day you went back to work?  How did it go? 🫶🏻🫶🏻🫶🏻
.

 I will slowly turn these sketches into sculptures. Stay tuned. 

Have a beautiful weekend everyone. 

.
 
Beautiful studio photograph by @kes_____
.

“How do you keep making your art work when you have 3 kids?” One of the most common questions I get asked. Well, the simple answer is that I try to make my work everyday even if it is just a quick sketch like this piece. One thing that became clear in the last few years was the power of small progress. I need to be one step closer to who I want to become as a human and an artist. It can be a baby step. It means I work even if I can only find a couple hours slot in-between breast feedings per day. Sometimes I manage to do a gigantic step when 3 of them are napping at the same time. (It almost never happens.) The bottom line is that I need to witness progress with a higher purpose goal in me. Then I can let go of my day being hijacked by them. Even better, I actually enjoy being fully present with their crazy wild world once I’ve made my small progress. More effective at getting things done, less resentful about my motherhood. I stopped focusing on the quantity of time I spend at home too. I only focus on quality time with them.  I used to find myself  being around my kids but I was often not fully present. And finally I try not to compare myself with other cool mamas! (Well, trying not to at least.) 
.

A TALISMAN FOR THE HISTORY SHE MAKES
 
For the career woman, yesterday’s teen pregnancy is today’s twenty-something mum. We view a child in our 20’s as a setback to our ambitions. We struggle with a lack of mothering instinct, believe we’re not a ‘baby person’, or that kids get in the way of our success. We may be highly educated, well travelled, hard working, yet we watch our 20’s fly by, our 30’s too, our whole life driven by career - until the day we wake up to our reproductive reality. And we’re seized with the terror of losing everything we’ve strived for (our career, our freedom, our way of life) because of the negative way motherhood is portrayed in society.
 
With a new born in my late 30’s, a second and third in my 40’s, truth is it’s tough to maintain a career, a meaningful relationship with your partner, AND raise children. It’s intense. More so when you both have demanding professions. A fully functioning family appears almost like a myth.
 
My Dogu Ladies are a salute to the strength of the career mother, her resilience and determination. Recognition that what she does is without historical precedent - with no past to guide us, these vases are a talisman for the history we create ourselves. 
 
 
*Dogu - mysterious female figurines from prehistoric Japan (14,000-400BC approx). With big eyes, accentuated large breasts and wide hips, they are widely held to be symbols of fertility, a promise of safe delivery for baby and mother, hope for the continuation of life.

.

I wish I had known this sooner.
 
I get a lot of portfolios and questions from people who just graduated. How to become an artist(and live off from it)? Unfortunately most of art school does not teach us how to survive after graduation.
 
1: Do not quit. I know this sounds obvious but if you quit making your art now, that’s it. Game over. So do not quit.
 
2: Work insanely hard “single mindedly” and see where it takes you. If you don’t aim for something, you cannot achieve it. Just as an archer who does not aim will likely miss their target. I promise you that an opportunity will unfold as you take a step toward your goal.
 
3: Reduce your living cost as much as you can.  So you are not over-whelmed with financial needs. Too much immediate comfort will cost your life in the end. Comfort will only comfort you in a short term.
 
4: Side hustle. Do not underestimate the power of your side hustle. I had endless side jobs to finance my art practice for years. Waitress, nanny, art direction, graphic deign, teaching, Air B&B, selling stuff on a street…etc etc! Do not worry this side job life will eventually end. Do not get comfortable with your side job, tho. (I did. That’s another story!) At least 50% of your time should always be working on your art work.
 
5: Get your art work out in the world. More eye balls can see your art work the better.
 
6: Decide what your definition of success as an artist. And say it out loud to your friends and family.  This helps your goals feel solid, real, and made them crystal clear and sharp. More over so you would know when you are falling short. Don’t deliberately keep your goals obscure, so no one knows you’re failing to achieve them, or worse, to fool yourself.
 
7: Write your artist statement. If you can write, that means you can think. Your art work will be effective in the real world. It helps people to understand your art. It will help your gallery to sell your work. You can lay out a proposal and apply for your artist bursaries. Art school unfortunately does not teach us to be articulate enough and that kills us once we graduate as we cannot just hide behind pretty colours.

The science of mamahood and career.
 
No1 question in my inbox. How do you keep up with your career and motherhood? I wish I know the answer! I’m just figuring things out as I go but here’re a few things I can share with you. Hope it’s helpful. (Note: My kids are 5, 2 and 12 months old)
 
 
1: Fight for your studio time. I am still breast-feeding my baby so I have 3-4 hours per day at the moment. I don’t waste any minutes of it. Creative people are often sensitive to negative experience and stressful situation. (well, I am!) Mamahood is beautiful but man, intense and stressful. It’s deadly to you and your family if your mind is chaos and full of negativity. So fight for your studio time. Even your art work may not be financially contributing to a family pot. Alternative is worse. So fight.
 
 
2: Progress. I make sure at least I progress one thing in the studio every day. Finishing a sketch, making a model, writing artist statement etc. This tangible proof that I’m getting closer to the artist who I want to become, is a game changer. Then I can let go of my day being hijacked by the kids. Even better, I actually enjoy being fully present with their crazy wild world once I’ve made my small progress.
 
 
3: Maybe cliché but quality over quantity. Working mama is always so guilty of not spending enough time with the kids. It’s easy to be half-assly around with them while your head is half in the world of scrolling. Turn it off.
 
4: Articulate your definition of success with your partner. So your partner knows how to help you and share the childcare. Make it as precise as possible. I.E  one collection by September, exhibition and one public sculpture this year.
 
5: Do not compare with another super mama on a social media. You don’t know anything about her true life. It’s pointless.
 
6: Humour. Man, kids are funny! Mama who laughs, lasts.
 
7: No right way to a mamahood.  Do your thing, gal.  My motherhood has helped me better identify my creative capacity, grow more creatively courageous, and take action in pursuit of my art, while still holding what I see as a noble goal.
 
Here’s to mamahood🫶🏻

🇬🇧 New Exhibition in London. 🇬🇧 
.
‘The Artisan Collab at 45 Park Lane’ curated by Giovanna Ticciati.
 
The exhibition will show the work of exceptional designers, makers and artists: beautifully made pieces from jewellery to sculpture and paintings. These seemingly disparate pieces celebrate the expression of something deep in us all they share, pieces imagined in solitude yet we all understand.

Comprised of nine international artisans, artists and designers, the exhibition shows the best in modern craftsmanship and technique through a variety of disciplines. 

This exhibition is part of 45 Park Lane’s art programme which is curated by @ackermanstudios, and brings together established and emerging international talent. 
 
5th September - 5th November
45 Park Lane
London W1K 1PN
 
45 Park Lane a 5* hotel that is open to all, it is a wonderful place to meet for a drink. It also has two restaurants, Cut and Sushi Kanesaka. It is next door to The Dorchester and is part of The Dorchester Collection.
 
The full line-up of the exhibition’s collaborators:
1.  Kate Boxer - artist @kate_e_boxer
2.  Pippa Small - jeweller @pippasmalljewellery
3.  Lucy Whitford - ceramic artist @lucywhitford.studio
4.  Bénédicte Vallet - ceramicist - none
5.  Benoît Averley - sculptor @benoitaverly_sculptor
6.  Gennaro Avallone - artist & designer @laboratoriogennaroavallone
7.  Bruce Rae - photographer - none 
8.  Noe Kuremoto - ceramic artist - @noe_kuremoto_ceramics
9.  Tom Palmer - artist, designer and maker @tom_palmerstudio

45 Park Lane a 5* hotel that is open to all, it is a wonderful place to meet for a drink. It also has two restaurants, Cut and Sushi Kanesaka. It is next door to The Dorchester and is part of The Dorchester Collection.
 
The full line-up of the exhibition’s collaborators:
1.  Kate Boxer - artist @kate_e_boxer
2.  Pippa Small - jeweller @pippasmalljewellery
3.  Lucy Whitford - ceramic artist @lucywhitford.studio
4.  Bénédicte Vallet - ceramicist - none
5.  Benoît Averley - sculptor @benoitaverly_sculptor
6.  Gennaro Avallone - artist & designer @laboratoriogennaroavallone
7.  Bruce Rae - photographer - none 
8.  Noe Kuremoto - ceramic artist - @noe_kuremoto_ceramics
9.  Tom Palmer - artist, designer and maker @tom_palmerstudio

🌸 I really enjoy making a bespoke vessel. The process of making a vase for a floral artist is completely different from making my usual sculpture. Floral artist is the one who is going to do the final magic touch and a vase cannot be too loud. Otherwise we cannot hear the music of flowers.  My eternal thank you to the wonderful floral community for having me. Thank you.

I make a lot of Haniwa warriors. Most of the time I’m only happy with a couple of them in the end. I wish I knew which one turns my head around before I spend days. I wish I knew which one makes my heart beats louder before I fire them. 🤪Here he is just came out the kiln this morning. Suffice to say that I’m in love. 🫶🏻.

Daily Shodo #138 空 “Space” 
 
Shodō is the art of traditional Japanese calligraphy. A brush gracefully sweeps across white paper. I still vividly remember the smell of deep black Sumi ink. As youngsters, every morning we had to write Kanji characters that anticipated our day ahead. We were told the process would engrave the ideal into our minds, to help make it real. Considered a spiritual practice of awakening, it plays an integral part of Japanese life. With our universe revealed to us by this most simple of actions – a brush stroke on paper leads to the answer.

Though we may not even know what we have within us, let’s take one stupidly small step forward from yesterday together. Let the answer unfold through our action, however tiny.

A journey towards the ideal. This is how I returned to my Shodō practice.

“With each new collection, my mind kicks and screams, as I drag myself to the studio, fighting my anxiety monster every step of the way: Nobody cares about your art, it says, Who’d want to buy this? You’ll never get where you want to be. You’re already over 40. You’re not spending enough time with your kids. You’re not half the person you should be and you know it.” And there’s a paralysing sensation that the monster’s right - I do know I’m not all I could be...”

 
 
“…Accepted wisdom tells us: To be an artist is to sacrifice all for your art. Similarly it says: To be a mother is to sacrifice all for your children. I constantly feel inferior to these lofty ideals. Perhaps many career driven people share the exact same feeling…”

 

 

(Please see the slide 3-8 for the unedited version. Thank you )

.

For you whose life has been hijacked by kids

For you who feel too old to start something new

For you who hit the snooze button a million times

For you who excel in procrastination

For you who await miracles of free time to write your first novel

Or who believe the market will decide when you start that dream project

For you who imagine the ideal conditions to start your second career are just around the corner

For you who fear the blank page

For you whose ears burn, set alight by the opinion of others

For you who believe your identity is locked down tight, never free to adapt or change

For you who still pursue a definition of success set by your 20-something self

For you who know something more important is calling but are too scared to answer

For you who are afraid to fail

For you who the Ideal messes with your head - who are paralysed by your vision of perfection…

who laugh at a small step

who wait for the perfect moment to begin

For you who the pain of ‘not doing’ is not yet bad enough

Today’s the day we do not just sit there

Now’s the time to we show who’s in a charge of our destiny: WE ARE.

That first dot, that first stroke, first word, first note, each and every single day is our super power.

Let’s take one stupidly small step forward, together, this instant.

And let the answers unfold through our actions, however tiny.

 

Hello Ideal, we’re coming for you!

 

Noe Kuremoto 2023

“…By the time I was a mother to 3 kids, my life was unrecognisable from before. Once work was all-consuming, my latest project my full focus... Work had to change… Now, as a parent, I get just 3 sacred hours in my studio per day..”

 

“…With each new collection, my mind kicks and screams, as I drag myself to the studio, fighting my anxiety monster every step of the way: Nobody cares about your art, it says, Who’d want to buy this? You’ll never get where you want to be. You’re already over 40. You’re not spending enough time with your kids. You’re not half the person you should be and you know it.”

And there’s a paralysing sensation that the monster’s right - I do know I’m not all I could be...

 

For my full project write up, please read Slide 2-9. Thank you.

 

A big gratitude is in order today.
I’m so glad my personal journey of motherhood and clayhood has resonated with so many people. Wow. My heart is beating so loud and so touched by every single message and endless encouraging comments. It’s so gratifying that it’s almost too much! I used to organize my brain with conversations with friends and other artists but mamahood keeps me busy and away from it. It can feel isolated…so all your messages mean so much to me.  Thank you for sharing your stories with me. Thank you for letting me tell my story. Thank you for not letting me lose my mind in the midst of motherhood and clayhood.
